docs.title: Mental Models
docs.text: A mental model is a compression of how something works. Any idea, belief, or concept can be distilled down. Like a map, mental models reveal key information while ignoring irrelevant details. Models concentrate the world into understandable and useable chunks. - https://fs.blog/mental-models/

docs.title: Attack Life Cycle -> RINSE & Repeat
docs.text:
Attackers always RINSE & repeat:

  • Reconnaissance - Gather information: to assess value & vulnerabilities aka System Susceptibility
  • Infiltrate Networks - Get into target networks relates to Threat Accessibility
  • Spread Laterally - Stay inside target networks, relates to Threat Capability to stay undetected
  • Execute Objectives - Ultimately to compromise target networks' Confidentiality, Integrity & Availability objectives

Understand how attacks can be disrupted by design & not by reacting to problems & adding more Tit-for-Tat controls.

Click here to dive deeper...

docs.title: Tactics Techniques & Procedures
docs.text:
The original context of "Tactics, Techniques, and Procedures" (TTP) is rooted in military terminology, specifically within the Department of Defense. TTPs are used to describe the employment and ordered arrangement of forces in relation to each other (tactics), the non-prescriptive methods used to perform missions or tasks (techniques), and the standard, detailed steps that prescribe how to perform specific tasks (procedures).

In cybersecurity, TTPs have been adapted to describe the behavior of threat actors and the structured framework for executing cyberattacks. Understanding TTPs is crucial for identifying, analyzing, and responding to security threats. Tactics refer to the strategic (WHAT) objectives of an attacker, techniques are the (HOW) methods used to achieve these objectives, and procedures are the specific (WHEN) steps taken to execute the techniques.

docs.title: Direct vs Indirect Access to Objectives
docs.text:
Directly from 1.Recon to 4.Execute Objectives -> Poor web-server configuration leads to exposure of unprotected sensitive files that can be downloaded by anyone. Can't even consider this as an attack, low hanging fruits for adversaries!

From 1.Recon to 2.Infiltrate Networks -> Attackers use LinkedIn to figure out who are the HR executives, send deceptive emails to lure them (Phishing) to click on malicious links or execute malware. Just need one employee to give attackers that chance to gain control over a HR asset when the malware infects like a Patient Zero & persists within that endpoint. Why go through all that tedium when attackers can buy access into corporate VPN?

First scenario clear illustrates the 3 conditions, valuable information in the form of files are there left exposed, anyone can explore such web-server directories without being noticed, attackers just scan a range of Internet addresses to find such poorly configured servers.

Success or failure of cyber-physical attack depends on Necessary and Sufficient prerequisites. Attacks are effective only when all conditions are fulfilled, yet it will fail if any single condition is disrupted. For instance, if employees are vigilant, they ignore the phishing emails. With robust multi-factor VPN authentication, losing 1st factor of ID & password to dark web is less threatening.

docs.title: Disrupt Attack by Design instead of Reacting to...
docs.text:
We have been conditioned by the industry to react to yet another vulnerability announcement, wait for vendors to release patches (e.g. Microsoft Patch Tuesday) or worst, an automatic update that disrupted millions of hosts. Yet another fancy Threat Actor name/brand from whatever "Intelligence Report".

All that is part of what I termed as Chase-After-Bad posture, which is unending & costly.

Threat Accessibility is the condition that we can disrupt attacks effectively by design & architecture with usability & security in mind.

What about the other two conditions?

  • Keeping up with vulnerabilities by patching (2018 RDP issue after patch, 2024 July patch broke RDP again) is very challenging & sometimes disastrous, like the one that brought down millions of Windows hosts.
  • Threat actors are extremely motivated, creative & resourceful, defenders are mostly burnt-out by the complexity & challenges.

Beyond explaining why Threat Accessibility is the viable condition to disrupt with Attack Life Cycle mental model, the other important message is to urge system architects to avoid Tit-for-Tat controls that put yourself in a Chase-After-Bad posture.

docs.title: Replace Tit-for-Tat Controls with Design Thinking
docs.text:
The Crowdstrike Channel File incident is a prime example of Tit-for-Tat control. Whenever there's some new offensive method, they release yet another update.

It is quite easy to assess: so long you need to constantly update whenever some new technique emerge, then it is a Tit-for-Tat control. These controls tend to be attack technique specific.

By Design Thinking, it doesn't mean more pretty or shining new tech but how we can make it easy for legit users but yet costly for attackers. Let's use a short but concrete example with reasonable cost-benefit breakdown to illustrate what I mean by Design Thinking.

...illustrate with Windows client zone vs iPad as desktop...

This leads to another important concept known as Attack Surface Management!

docs.title: Notions
docs.text: The word "Notions" effectively combines the essence of both "notes" and "thoughts." It conveys the idea of ideas or concepts that are recorded or contemplated, making it a fitting choice for a term that encapsulates both elements.
